DOC.brief_title: Effect of Betablocker or Aldosterone Antagonist Therapy on Patients With Liver Cirrhosis
DOC.detailed_description: Cardio-pulmonal complications to patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension determine the patients' prognosis. Most patients have hemodynamical changes in circulation with increased cardiac output and decreased systolic function in stress. Endothelial dysfunction is a parameter for bad prognosis in cardiovascular disease. The Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system plays an important role in natrium and volume regulation. Descriptions of changes in the peripheral circulation and oxygenation have been deficient up to now. Patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension are betablockers and/or aldosterone antagonists routine treatment - effects on peripheral hemodynamics and oxygenation in relation to central hemodynamic changes are deficient.
DOC.criteria: Liver cirrhosis Clinical indication for treatment with betablocker or aldosterone antagonist Must not have been treated earlier with betablocker or aldosterone antagonist Must have been alcohol abstinent for more than 4 weeks Gastrointestinal bleeding in the last 2 weeks Encephalopathy > grade 1 Acute medical conditions Malignant disease Pregnancy
